Article Title: Amazon and Starbucks workers are on strike. Why and how Donald Trump may have something to do with this
Article Text:
Amazon workers strike outside the gates of an Amazon Fulfillment Center. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

The 'likely Trump' factor behind the strikes

Amazon and Starbucks is joined by Elon Musk's Starlink

Strikes are underway at Amazon and Starbucks in several US cities as workers push for Union recognition and improved contracts. These actions follow a year of significant labour wins for Unions at companies like Boeing, and among dockworkers, video game performers, and Las Vegas casino workers. So what's behind the strikes at Amazon and Starbucks?Amazon reportedly refuses to formally acknowledge unionization efforts by its drivers and warehouse workers, despite some successful union votes and the Teamsters union claiming to represent them. Starbucks, while having agreed to negotiate, is facing criticism for slow progress.These strikes, particularly timed around the holiday season, aim to maximize pressure on the companies. The organizing drives at both companies gained momentum after the COVID-19 pandemic, which highlighted the importance of frontline workers and economic inequality. This period also saw successful unionization efforts at other retailers like Apple, Trader Joe's, and REI.A key factor driving the timing of these strikes is the upcoming change in presidential administration. With the potential for a less union-friendly National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) under a new administration, unions are attempting to leverage public pressure now. While some recent political appointments suggest a potentially more nuanced stance on labour relations, the immediate future of the NLRB remains a concern for unions.John Logan, director of labor and employment studies at San Francisco State University, told news agency AP that he thinks the Amazon and Starbucks workers are ‚Äúdesperate‚Äù to make progress before President-elect Donald Trump gets to appoint a Republican majority to the National Labor Relations Board, which is expected to be less friendly to unions during his administration.‚ÄúThe unions want to make these disputes public and bring political pressures on the companies," Logan said in a written statement. ‚ÄúIf these disputes drag on until next year, and if they are fought largely through the labor board and the courts, the unions and workers will almost certainly lose. This might be their last, best chance to pressure the companies in public before Trump comes into office.‚ÄùAmazon reportedly objected to the 2022 warehouse election results, reportedly claiming that the Amazon Labor Union and the federal labour board had tainted the vote. A regional NLRB director issued a complaint last year that accused Amazon of violating the law by refusing to bargain with the union.Amazon, in turn, is challenging the constitutionality of the NLRB in federal court along with Elon Musk 's SpaceX. In June, the US Supreme Court made it harder for the agency to win court orders in labour disputes, siding with Starbucks in a case brought by the company.
Article Summary: Strikes are underway at Amazon and Starbucks in several US cities as workers push for Union recognition and improved contracts. A key factor driving the timing of these strikes is the upcoming change in presidential administration. With the potential for a less union-friendly National Labor Relations Board under a new administration, unions are attempting to leverage public pressure now.

Article Title: Qualcomm wins its legal battle against Arm, but why the problems may not be all over for it
Article Text:
FILE PHOTO: Qualcomm logo is during Munich Auto Show, IAA Mobility 2021 in Munich, Germany, September 8, 2021. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

Qualcomm secured a win in its licensing dispute with Arm, but the legal battle may be far from over after a federal jury in Delaware delivered a mixed verdict on last week that resulted in a partial mistrial.The jury sided with Qualcomm on two crucial points, finding that the chipmaker didn't violate Arm's licensing agreement when it acquired chip design startup Nuvia for $1.4 billion in 2021. The verdict also confirmed that Qualcomm's existing architecture license with Arm covered the continued development of custom CPU cores obtained through the Nuvia acquisition .However, the jury deadlocked on whether Nuvia itself breached its original licensing agreement with Arm, prompting U.S. District Court Judge Maryellen Noreika to suggest mediation between the two tech giants. Arm has already announced its intention to seek a retrial.The case stems from Arm's 2022 lawsuit alleging that Qualcomm improperly continued developing Nuvia's custom CPU cores without obtaining necessary permissions after the acquisition. These cores, now renamed Oryon , are crucial to Qualcomm's strategy to compete with Intel and AMD in the PC market through its Snapdragon X processors.Evidence presented during the trial revealed underlying tensions in the companies' relationship, with internal documents showing Qualcomm projected potential annual savings of up to $1.4 billion in Arm licensing fees through the Nuvia acquisition.While Qualcomm celebrated the verdict as a vindication of its "right to innovate," Arm expressed disappointment over the jury's inability to reach consensus on all claims. The outcome leaves uncertainty hanging over the future of Qualcomm's PC chip ambitions, as Arm seeks to protect what it calls its "unparalleled ecosystem" built over three decades.
Article Summary: A federal jury in Delaware delivered a mixed verdict on last week that resulted in a partial mistrial. The jury sided with Qualcomm on two crucial points, finding that the chipmaker didn't violate Arm's licensing agreement when it acquired chip design startup Nuvia for $1.4 billion in 2021. The verdict also confirmed that Qualcomm's existing architecture license with Arm covered the continued development of custom CPU cores obtained through the Nuvia acquisition.

How to identify a digital arrest scam

Unexpected Contact from ‚ÄòOfficials‚Äô: Be cautious if someone claims to be from government agencies like the police, CBI, income tax officers, or customs agents, contacts you. Be cautious especially if they claim urgent legal action is being initiated or warranted. They might allege that you or one of your family members is involved in a serious crime like money laundering, tax evasion, or drug trafficking.

Fear-based language and urgency: Scammers may request video calls, disguising themselves in police uniforms, using government logos, or creating official-sounding background noise to appear legitimate. They often threaten arrest or immediate legal action, demanding a quick response and using legal terms to sound convincing. In some cases, they create a police station-like set up to further convince victims of their credibility.

Request for sensitive information or payment: Scammers may ask for personal information or demand large sums of money, promising that this will clear up your involvement in the alleged crime. They may also coerce you to transfer money to their account until the investigation is complete. Terms like ‚Äúclearing your name‚Äù, ‚Äúassisting with the investigation‚Äù, or ‚Äúrefundable security deposit/escrow account‚Äù might be used by them to persuade you into transferring money to specified bank accounts or UPI IDs.

Tips to stay safe

Pause and Verify: If you receive unexpected calls or messages about legal issues, take a moment to verify. Stay calm, as scammers rely on fear and urgency. Real government and law enforcement agencies will never ask for money or investigate cases through phone or video calls. Always confirm the caller‚Äôs identity and consult trusted sources before taking any action.

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‚Äòparty‚Äô booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

Article Title: South Korean researchers develop ‚ÄòIron Man‚Äô robot to help differently abled users
Article Text:
How this robot works



"It can approach me wherever I am, even when I'm sitting in a wheelchair, and be worn to help me stand up, which is one of its most distinct features,"

"I wanted to tell my son .... that I also used to able to walk. I wanted to share a diverse range of experiences with him,"

South Korean researchers have developed a lightweight wearable robot that can assist paraplegic users in walking, manoeuvring obstacles, and climbing stairs. The robot can walk up to the differently abled users and lock itself onto them to help them with these movements. The Exoskeleton Laboratory team at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) that has developed this robot aims to integrate this technology into the daily lives of differently abled people. Park Jeong-su, a member of the KAIST team, shared that his inspiration came from the movie Iron Man .‚ÄúAfter watching Iron Man, I thought it would be great if I can help people with a robot in real life,‚Äù Jeong-su said to the news agency Reuters.According to a report by Reuters, the powered exoskeleton, named WalkON Suit F1 , features an aluminium and titanium composition to weigh in at 50kg and is powered by 12 electronic motors that simulate the movements of human joints while walking.The robot is designed to maintain the user's balance while walking, using sensors in its soles and upper body that process 1,000 signals per second to predict the user's intended movements.According to Jeong-su, the robot's front-facing lenses act as eyes that analyse the environment, measure stair heights, and detect obstacles. This functionality compensates for the sensory limitations of users with complete paraplegia.Kim Seung-hwan, a paraplegic and a member of the KAIST team, showcased the prototype. The robot enabled him to walk at a speed of 3.2 km/h (2 mph), ascend a flight of stairs, and take lateral steps to slide onto a bench, the report noted.Seung-hwan said in a statement to the news agency Reuters.While wearing the WalkON Suit F1, he even secured a gold medal in the exoskeleton category at Cybathlon 2024 , an event where individuals with diverse physical disabilities showcased assistive robots across eight categories.Seung-hwan noted.

Article Title: WhatsApp may stop working on these Android smartphones starting next week

Article Title: Elon Musk vs Jeff Bezos space fight is entering a new era and here's what may give Amazon founder an edge
Article Text:
Elon Musk‚Äôs SpaceX: The undisputed leader in space

The stakes for space exploration

Challenges and opportunities ahead

Also read |

|

|

The rivalry between Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos , the two wealthiest men in the world, has entered a pivotal phase as their respective companies, SpaceX and Blue Origin , lead the charge in commercial space exploration. While Musk's SpaceX has dominated the space industry for nearly two decades, Bezos is making bold moves to challenge this dominance through Blue Origin‚Äôs New Glenn rocket and Amazon‚Äôs Project Kuiper. These developments mark a significant chapter in the billionaire space race, potentially reshaping the landscape of space exploration and satellite-based internet services.Since its inception in 2002, SpaceX has revolutionized the space industry. The company‚Äôs reusable rocket technology, pioneered with the Falcon 9, has drastically reduced the cost of launches while increasing their frequency. SpaceX completed over 130 launches in 2023 alone, accounting for 85% of the total orbital mass deployed that year.SpaceX‚Äôs Starlink satellite network, launched in 2018, has also become a game-changer, with over 6,000 satellites in orbit and more than 4 million users worldwide. Starlink provides internet access to remote areas, supporting uses as diverse as military operations in Ukraine and connectivity for rural households in the U.S. This vertical integration, where SpaceX both manufactures satellites and launches them, has given Musk an unparalleled advantage in the industry.While Bezos founded Blue Origin around the same time as SpaceX, its progress has been comparatively slower. The company has primarily focused on suborbital tourism, offering brief trips to the edge of space. However, Bezos has invested heavily in developing the New Glenn rocket, which aims to compete directly with SpaceX‚Äôs Falcon 9.New Glenn, a towering rocket as tall as a 32-story building, is equipped with a reusable booster designed for frequent satellite launches. Currently stationed at Cape Canaveral, Florida, New Glenn is awaiting regulatory approval for its first orbital launch, expected in early 2024.In addition to Blue Origin, Bezos is leveraging Amazon‚Äôs resources to develop Project Kuiper, a satellite internet network designed to rival SpaceX‚Äôs Starlink. With a planned constellation of 3,232 satellites, Project Kuiper aims to provide global internet coverage, focusing on areas underserved by traditional infrastructure.Although delayed until 2025, Project Kuiper successfully tested two prototype satellites in 2023. Amazon has invested over $16 billion in the project and constructed a satellite manufacturing facility near Seattle. Notably, Project Kuiper has already secured partnerships with Blue Origin and United Launch Alliance for satellite launches, though it has also contracted SpaceX for three launches starting in 2025.Both billionaires view space as more than a business opportunity. Musk envisions a future where humanity colonizes Mars to ensure survival against potential Earth-bound disasters. His focus on sustainability and manufacturing capacity highlights his long-term commitment to Blue Origin‚Äôs success.While SpaceX maintains a significant lead, analysts believe competition from Blue Origin and Amazon‚Äôs Project Kuiper is critical for industry growth. Article Title: Donald Trump calls TikTok ‚Äúsucker‚Äù, adds we may need to keep it for sometime as ‚Ä¶
Article Text:
Donald Trump (AP file photo)

US President-elect Donald Trump indicated Sunday he may favor allowing TikTok to continue operating in the United States, citing his campaign's successful engagement on the platform just weeks before a potential nationwide ban takes effect."I think we're going to have to start thinking because, you know, we did go on TikTok, and we had a great response with billions of views, billions and billions of views," Trump told the crowd at AmericaFest, an annual gathering organized by conservative group Turning Point."They brought me a chart, and it was a record, and it was so beautiful to see, and as I looked at it, I said, 'Maybe we gotta keep this sucker around for a little while,'" he said.The comments follow Trump's Monday meeting with TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew at Mar-a-Lago, where Trump expressed having a "warm spot" for the app.Trump‚Äôs recent comments mark a significant shift from his previous stance during his first term when he attempted to ban the platform.The social media app faces a January 19 deadline to be sold by its Chinese parent company ByteDance or face removal from US app stores, following legislation signed by President Biden in April. The deadline falls one day before Trump takes office.ByteDance has challenged the law's constitutionality, and the Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on January 10. TikTok maintains that its content recommendation engine and user data are stored in the United States on Oracle Corp servers, while content moderation decisions affecting US users are made domestically.However, it remains unclear how Trump could reverse the divestiture order, which passed with strong bipartisan support in the Senate. The Justice Department continues to argue that Chinese control of TikTok poses national security risks, a position backed by most US lawmakers.The potential ban could affect 170 million US users and, according to TikTok, could result in significant revenue losses for small businesses and content creators. Apple and Google have reportedly been instructed to prepare for removing TikTok from their app stores if the deadline is not met.

Article Title: How a man lost Rs 6.6 lakh to 'Canara Bank KYC link‚Äô sent on WhatsApp
Article Text:
Here‚Äôs what happened in the WhatsApp APK file scam



What are APK malware



A Mangaluru resident reportedly lost Rs 6.6 lakh in an APK file scam on WhatsApp. The victim received a deceptive message from a WhatsApp group, which seemed like being from Canara Bank and warned him of account closure unless details were updated through a provided link. The victim downloaded the link, which led to a fraudulent bank interface requesting sensitive information. According to a complaint filed at Kavoor Police Station (seen by TOI) unauthorised transactions of Rs 6.6 lakh were made from the account despite him not sharing OTPs.The incident unfolded when the victim received a deceptive message in a WhatsApp group, seemingly from Canara Bank. Last week, the WhatsApp group "Durgi Cricket Utsava" was reportedly renamed to "Canara Bank." The group message warned that the complainant's Canara Bank account would be blocked unless UIDAI and KYC details were updated through an APK link.Trusting the message, the victim downloaded the APK, which led to a page mimicking a bank interface. The page requested sensitive details, including the mobile number, UIDAI number, ATM PIN, and CVV. Upon entering this information, the victim received OTPs on their mobile phone.Although the OTPs were not shared, the complainant later discovered that Rs 6.6 lakh had been fraudulently transferred from their account in multiple transactions using a debit card.Recognising the fraud, the victim said to TOI that he promptly blocked the card and reported the matter to the police. A case has been registered at Kavoor Police Station, and the investigation is underway.APK malware poses a significant threat to WhatsApp users. Cybercriminals create deceptive messages, often impersonating trusted entities, to trick users into downloading and installing dangerous APK files.Once installed, these files can steal sensitive information, intercept SMS messages, and compromise financial security. Users should be cautious about downloading and installing apps from unknown sources, especially those received through WhatsApp.
Article Summary: A Mangaluru resident reportedly lost Rs 6.6 lakh in an APK file scam on WhatsApp. The victim received a deceptive message from a WhatsApp group, which seemed like being from Canara Bank. The message warned him of account closure unless details were updated through a provided link. Victim downloaded the link, which led to a fraudulent bank interface requesting sensitive information.

Recent media reports suggesting a $600 million price tag for the wedding of billionaire Jeff Bezos and his fianc√©e, Lauren Sanchez , have been unequivocally dismissed by Bezos himself. The Amazon founder took to the social media platform X (formerly Twitter) to debunk the claims, emphasizing the importance of not believing every headline. Investor Bill Ackman also weighed in, casting doubt on the plausibility of such an exorbitant expense.Jeff Bezos directly addressed the reports on X, calling them "completely false" and urging people to exercise caution when consuming information online. Article Title: 'Sunny Leone' has been receiving Rs 1,000 monthly under the Chhattisgarh's Mahatari Vandan Yojana since March 2024
Article Text:
What is Chhattisgarh's Mahtari Vandan Yojana

In a recent incident in Chhattisgarh, a man named Virendra Joshi allegedly exploited the state's Mahtari Vandan Yojana by registering an account under the name of Bollywood actress Sunny Leone. This scheme, launched in March 2024, provides Rs 1,000 monthly to married women to promote women's empowerment.According to a report by The Economic Times, the BJP government's scheme provides Rs 1,000 per month to married women in the state. The fraud was uncovered in Talur village, Bastar district. District Collector Haris S has ordered an investigation and the seizure of the bank account. Officials revealed that media reports exposed the fraud.Joshi, a resident of Talur village in Bastar district, reportedly created an online bank account in Sunny Leone's name and had been receiving the monthly payments since the scheme's inception. The fraud came to light when officials noticed the unusual beneficiary name during a routine audit. An FIR has been lodged against Joshi, and authorities are investigating how the fraudulent registration bypassed the verification process.The incident has sparked political controversy, with the opposition Congress party alleging widespread corruption in the scheme. State Congress chief Deepak Baij claimed that over 50% of the beneficiaries under the Mahtari Vandan Yojana are fake. In response, Deputy Chief Minister Arun Sao defended the program, stating that the Congress is upset because women are now receiving assistance they didn't receive during the Congress's previous term.Chhattisgarh's Mahtari Vandan Yojana is a welfare scheme aimed at providing financial assistance to eligible married women. Under this scheme, beneficiaries receive Rs 1,000 per month.To qualify for the scheme, the following conditions must be met:1. Personal bank account: The woman must have her own bank account, as joint accounts are not accepted under the program.2. Aadhaar card and mobile number: The Aadhaar card and a mobile number registered with the bank account are mandatory.3. Account requirements: The Aadhaar card must be linked to the woman‚Äôs bank account, and Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) should be activated to receive the monthly payments.By ensuring these requirements are fulfilled, eligible women can seamlessly access the financial benefits provided under the Mahtari Vandan Yojana.
Article Summary: Chhattisgarh's Mahtari Vandan Yojana is a welfare scheme aimed at providing financial assistance to eligible married women. Under this scheme, beneficiaries receive Rs 1,000 per month. The fraud came to light when officials noticed the unusual beneficiary name during a routine audit. The incident has sparked political controversy, with the opposition Congress party alleging widespread corruption in the scheme.
